abstract.p: Prof Jonathan L Rosner letter on physics questions expresses optimism that particle physicists will eventually understand pattern of masses and interactions of subunits of matter

block.p: The article ''10 Physics Questions to Ponder for a Millennium to Two'' misses a key point that has stumped particle physicists for years: the pattern of masses and interactions of the subunits of matter is nearly a complete mystery.

The situation resembles that in the 1950's and 1960's, when attempts to understand the zoo of elementary particles culminated in their description in terms of quarks -- a few building blocks account for hundreds of particles.

The article ''10 Physics Questions to Ponder for a Millennium to Two'' misses a key point that has stumped particle physicists for years: the pattern of masses and interactions of the subunits of matter is nearly a complete mystery.

The situation resembles that in the 1950's and 1960's, when attempts to understand the zoo of elementary particles culminated in their description in terms of quarks -- a few building blocks account for hundreds of particles.

Mendeleev's periodic table began as a classification scheme. Quantum mechanics and its application to atoms and nuclei solved the puzzle. We now recognize over 100 elements and their isotopes as built of electrons, protons and neutrons.
The Top 10 compilers ask if we may ever understand such details of particle physics as masses and interactions. It is worth being optimistic.
History has proved us capable of not only understanding the details, but using them to validate or disprove deep theories.
The writer is a physics professor at the University of Chicago.
